long_description:
Great cities attract unparalleled talent—New York is no exception. When it comes to literary geniuses, many have flocked to New York in search of inspiration; others merely craved the energy and multiculturalism of the urban scene.

Today, bookworms can trace the steps of their favorite writers. The first step is to head from your room at the Royalton New York Hotel to New York City’s Public Library to feel the wisdom wafting through every nook and cranny. Then, head out to the following historic sites.

Hotel Chelsea

The No. 1 item of this list is a New York landmark where some of the best writers of the 20th century converged. Hotel Chelsea hosted Mark Twain, Thomas Wolfe, Arthur Miller, Jack Kerouac, Arthur C. Clarke, Jean-Paul Sartre, to name a few. Although currently not in operation, the hotel is scheduled to reopen this year with luxury rooms and condos. We’ve yet to tell whether it will continue attracting literary legends.
Location: 222 23rd St W. New York

White Horse Tavern

White Horse Tavern boasts being the second oldest continuously-run tavern in New York. Considering that it was opened in 1880, it has seen its share of history. Dylan Thomas, Beat poets, Jack Kerouac, Norman Meiller, Bob Dylan and even Jim Morrison stopped to have a drink or two. A lot of the original decor and wood works are still preserved—no wonder it’s considered a landmark!
Location: 567 Hudson St, New York

Minetta Tavern

This Greenwich Village spot opened in 1937 and soon became a favorite hang-out of writers, poets and artists. Over the years, Ernest Hemingway, Ezra Pound, Eugene O'Neill, E. E. Cummings, Dylan Thomas and Joe Gould visited the formerly Italian restaurant and tavern. Minetta tavern now a 1-Michelin star Parisian steakhouse worth a visit as it merges its new upscale face with the old-fashioned New York tavern.
Location: 113 Macdougal St, New York.

Poe Park

A trip to the Bronx will take you to Edgar Allan Poe’s cottage in Fordham Village. Although Poe lived in many places around New York, here is where he wrote “The Bells,” “Eureka,” and “Annabel Lee.” The cottage is open to visitors, who can see authentic furniture and keepsakes, as well as learn about the part that the Bronx played in Poe’s work..  
Location: Grand Concourse, between E. 192 St. and E. Kingsbridge, Bronx

The Nuyorican Poets Cafe

East Village has been a literary haven for decades as it was home to forums that helped influence artists, writers and poets. Of these bars and cafés, The Nuyorican, established in the 70s, set itself apart for welcoming the work of playwrights, poets, and musicians who belonged to minorities. As time went by, The Nuyorican became a hub for social empowerment and creativity and today it’s regarded as one of the most respected creative forums in the United States.
Location: 236 East 3rd St. New York

When choosing a hotel in New York for bookworms and history lovers, the Royalton is the obvious choice. Our sophisticated rooms retain the decor of a time long gone… Come and see for yourself!
